title: USS Robert L. Wilson
text:
USS "Robert L. Wilson" (DD/DDE-847) was a of the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a>, named for <a href="United%20States%20Marine%20Corps">Marine</a> Private First Class <a href="Robert%20L.%20Wilson">Robert L. Wilson</a> (1920–1944), who was posthumously awarded the <a href="Medal%20of%20Honor">Medal of Honor</a> for "conspicuous gallantry" in the <a href="Battle%20of%20Tinian">Battle of Tinian</a>.
"Robert L. Wilson" was laid down by the <a href="Bath%20Iron%20Works">Bath Iron Works</a> Corp., <a href="Bath%2C%20Maine">Bath, Maine</a>, on 2 July 1945; <a href="Ship%20naming%20and%20launching">launched</a> on 5 January 1946; sponsored by Mrs. Joe Wilson; and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> in the <a href="Boston%20Navy%20Yard">Boston Navy Yard</a> on 28 March 1946.
Service history.
1946–1960.
Following shakedown in <a href="Cuba">Cuba</a>n waters, "Robert L. Wilson" sailed from <a href="Naval%20Station%20Norfolk">Norfolk, Virginia</a> on 23 July 1946 for a six-month tour of duty with the <a href="United%20States%20Sixth%20Fleet">6th Fleet</a> in the <a href="Mediterranean">Mediterranean</a>. Returning to the United States in February 1947, she spent the next two years based at <a href="Naval%20Station%20Newport">Newport, Rhode Island</a>, operating off the Atlantic Coast and in the <a href="Caribbean">Caribbean</a>.
After overhaul at <a href="Boston%20Navy%20Yard">Boston Navy Yard</a>, she stood out of <a href="Hampton%20Roads">Hampton Roads</a> on a <a href="midshipman%20cruise">midshipman cruise</a> to <a href="Plymouth">Plymouth</a>, <a href="England">England</a>; <a href="Cherbourg">Cherbourg</a>, <a href="France">France</a>; and <a href="Guantanamo%20Bay%20Naval%20Base">Guantanamo Bay</a>, Cuba. On 4 March 1950 "Robert L. Wilson" was redesignated an <a href="escort%20destroyer">escort destroyer</a> DDE-847. She finished out the year with a midshipman training cruise to <a href="Northern%20Europe">Northern Europe</a>, duty in the <a href="Mediterranean">Mediterranean</a> which included special <a href="antisubmarine%20warfare">antisubmarine warfare</a> (ASW) demonstrations, and hunter-killer (HUK) operations along the eastern seaboard from Norfolk.
On 1 January 1951, as the result of a fleet reorganization, "Robert L. Wilson" became a unit of Escort Squadron 4 (<a href="CortRon">CortRon</a> 4), and hoisted the <a href="Pennant%20%28commissioning%29">pennant</a> of Commander, Escort Division 42. By 30 June 1960, she had completed eight tours of service in the Mediterranean since commissioning, provided training for <a href="Officer%20Cadet%23United%20States">cadet</a>s of the <a href="United%20States%20Military%20Academy">United States Military Academy</a> along the eastern seaboard; and conducted the annual summer midshipmen cruises for the <a href="United%20States%20Naval%20Academy">United States Naval Academy</a>, stressing antisubmarine tactics.
On 1 July 1956, she was assigned to the newly established Destroyer Squadron 36 (<a href="DesRon">DesRon</a> 36), composed of destroyer escort types specially configured for anti-submarine missions and yet maintaining the capability to handle all destroyer missions. During the last week of November and the early part of December 1959, "Robert L. Wilson" and two other escort destroyers participated in Operation "Monsoon," manning <a href="sea-air%20rescue">sea-air rescue</a> stations for the Presidential flight to Europe from the United States. She then operated in the western Atlantic and Caribbean until a <a href="Norfolk%20Navy%20Yard">Norfolk Navy Yard</a> overhaul in the summer of 1960.
1961–1974.
Returning to Caribbean and Atlantic operations, in January 1961 "Robert L. Wilson" pursued the <a href="Portugal">Portuguese</a> <a href="Ocean%20liner">liner</a> SS "Santa Maria" which had been <a href="Santa%20Maria%20hijacking">seized by a group of revolutionaries</a>. An eight-day chase took "Wilson" and across the <a href="equator">equator</a> to <a href="Recife">Recife</a>, <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a>. Returning to Norfolk, "Robert L. Wilson" underwent a month of preparation, then departed on 8 June for her ninth Mediterranean cruise. She spent the fall and winter of 1961 operating in the western Atlantic out of Norfolk.
In January 1962, "Robert L. Wilson" participated in recovery operations for a <a href="Project%20Mercury">Project Mercury</a> manned space capsule. "Robert L. Wilson" deployed with Task Group Bravo to Northern Europe in February, returning to Norfolk in mid-June 1962. On 1 August 1962 she was again classified DD-847. In September 1962, "Wilson" and the other ships of Destroyer Division 362 deployed to Guantanamo Bay, Cuba as a unit under the command of the Naval Base Commander for the purpose of base defense, and was at Guantanamo and in adjacent waters during the <a href="Cuban%20Missile%20Crisis">Cuban Missile Crisis</a> in October. "Robert L. Wilson" returned to Norfolk in late November and operated locally until March 1963 when she entered the <a href="Philadelphia%20Navy%20Yard">Philadelphia Navy Yard</a> for a <a href="Fleet%20Rehabilitation%20and%20Modernization">Fleet Rehabilitation and Modernization</a> (FRAM) I modernization. Emerging from her overhaul period in 1964, she continued to serve with the <a href="United%20States%20Atlantic%20Fleet">Atlantic Fleet</a> for the balance of that year and throughout 1965.
After serving as gunfire support ship at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, in late January and early February 1966, "Robert L. Wilson" was assigned the abort station for the first unmanned <a href="Project%20Apollo">Apollo</a> <a href="AS-201">space shot</a>. In April and June she was rescue destroyer for , prime recovery ship for the <a href="Gemini%209">Gemini 9</a> space mission. Following ASW exercises, she made her 12th deployment to the Mediterranean on 22 July 1966, returning to Norfolk 17 December. Following service as schoolship for the <a href="Fleet%20Sonar%20School">Fleet Sonar School</a> in January and February, "Wilson" spent the rest of 1967 operating in the Atlantic and Caribbean.
"Robert L. Wilson" continued these operations until May 1968 when she joined the search for nuclear <a href="submarine">submarine</a> searching the continental shelf off the coast of Norfolk and then following the "Scorpion"s track back to her last reported position southwest of the <a href="Azores">Azores</a> without success. Returning to Norfolk on 13 June, "Wilson" operated in the Atlantic until steaming on 6 September for a <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">western Pacific</a> deployment.
Touching at <a href="Naval%20Station%20San%20Diego">San Diego</a>, <a href="Pearl%20Harbor">Pearl Harbor</a>, <a href="Midway%20Atoll">Midway</a>, <a href="Guam">Guam</a>, and <a href="Subic%20Bay">Subic Bay</a>, "Robert L. Wilson" took up a naval gunfire support mission 36 miles (67 km) south of <a href="Hu%E1%BA%BF">Huế</a>, the ancient capital of <a href="South%20Vietnam">South Vietnam</a>. She then undertook search and rescue duty in the <a href="Gulf%20of%20Tonkin">Gulf of Tonkin</a> after 28 October, destroying two <a href="sampan">sampan</a>s with .50 caliber <a href="machine%20gun">machine gun</a> fire and <a href="hand%20grenade">hand grenade</a>s. In early November "Robert L. Wilson" was assigned as plane guard for on "<a href="Yankee%20Station">Yankee Station</a>". She remained in the <a href="Far%20East">Far East</a> through the end of the year.
"Robert L. Wilson" returned to San Diego from the <a href="Far%20East">Far East</a> on 27 March 1969, and operated off the <a href="West%20Coast%20of%20the%20United%20States">west coast</a> until transiting the <a href="Panama%20Canal">Panama Canal</a> and arriving Norfolk on 21 June. She then operated in the western Atlantic and Caribbean participating in Operation SPRINGBOARD until deploying to the Mediterranean on 5 March 1970. During this Mediterranean cruise, "Wilson" participated in two combined <a href="NATO">NATO</a> exercises, DAWN PATROL and MEDTACEX, and was, for a time, diverted to the <a href="Levantine%20Basin">Levantine Basin</a> due to another <a href="Middle%20East">Middle East</a> crisis. She returned to Norfolk on 16 September for a leave, upkeep, and training cycle which continued to the end of the year.
Upon completion of overhaul, refresher training, and other operations in the Atlantic, "Robert L. Wilson" commenced another deployment to the <a href="United%20States%20Fifth%20Fleet">Sixth Fleet</a>, departing from Norfolk on 17 September. After six months away from Norfolk, she returned on 17 March 1972 and completed the year operating out of that port.
"Robert L. Wilson" <a href="Ship%20decommissioning">decommissioned</a> at Norfolk on 30 September 1974 and transferred to the inactive fleet facility at Philadelphia. She was struck from the <a href="Naval%20Vessel%20Register">Naval Vessel Register</a> on 30 September 1974 and sunk as a target as part of the <a href="Boeing%20Harpoon">Harpoon missile</a> test program on 1 March 1980.
Awards.
"Robert L. Wilson" earned three <a href="battle%20star">battle star</a>s for service in the <a href="Vietnam%20War">Vietnam War</a>.
